did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.abstract: Correspondence, bulletins, memoranda, reports, studies, lists, financial records, and photographs, relating to Polish foreign relations during World War II, the Polish government in exile in London, Allied diplomacy during World War II, conditions in Poland during the war, deportation of Poles to the Soviet Union, Polish refugees, the Jewish holocaust in Poland, and Polish military operations. Includes some records of Polish foreign relations during the interwar period. A digital copy of this entire collection is available at http://szukajwarchiwach.pl/800/42/0/-/.

scopecontent.head: Introduction
scopecontent.p: Now fully organized and provided with a detailed register, the collection of the Polish Foreign Ministry (Poland Ministerstwo Spraw Zagranicznych) at the Hoover Archives constitutes a unique resource for scholars studying not only Polish diplomatic history but the more general subjects of World War II and events surrounding the post-war division of Europe and the beginnings of the Cold War. If for no other reason, the particular status of Poland as victim of both Nazi and Soviet aggression explains the importance of the material in this collection, but it is of renewed interest in light of more recent developments. Five years after the fall of Communism, and with the resulting increased access to East European archives, the historical period covered by the collection has been subjected to a variety of reinterpretations based on newly available records. The collection provides a significant source of primary documentation on a wide range of topics pertinent to such a re-examination.

The history of the collection itself recapitulates many of the events described within its records, and it is directly linked to the fate of independent Poland. Unlike its European counterparts, the Polish state entered the twentieth century without a diplomatic tradition, having endured foreign occupation for more than 100 years. Following the achievement of independence in 1918, it would take many years for the Polish state to establish an official presence on the international level. Before World War II, Poland had still not completed the task of building a comprehensive diplomatic network. As of July 1, 1939, Poland had 10 embassies, 23 legations and 203 consular offices of diverse status throughout the world. This was a level of representation which was not commensurate with the needs of the Polish state.

After the outbreak of World War II with the simultaneous Russian and German invasions of Poland, the government was forced to relocate abroad and reconstruct its operations, including its diplomatic service. In the first months of exile in London, the Foreign Ministry's posts were filled by a new group of officials, who nonetheless were able to maintain a high level of professional competence in the exercise of their duties. Utilizing skilled individuals from among the Polish refugee population, as well as former employees who were smuggled out of occupied Poland, the ministry was able to preserve a clear division of responsibilities within its staff and to sustain an intense diplomatic effort on behalf of Poland. Having been forced to dramatically reduce its diplomatic service at the beginning of the war, the foreign ministry was able to re-establish its representation abroad, so that by the war's end there were some 148 Polish consular offices.

During the war, the Polish government was in the peculiar position of having no territory or subjects to rule and having its armies scattered on different continents. It remained in close touch with occupied Poland and with those who constituted the underground resistance. Each branch of the government in exile had its homologue within occupied Poland, and this kind of parallel operation was unique within occupied Europe. As no puppet governments emerged following the German and Russian invasions, the London government could make sole claim to represent the Polish nation. As part of this representation, it was concerned with preserving the records of the Polish state.

Already in the immediate period prior to the outbreak of hostilities in 1939, the Polish government had been concerned with the selection and transfer of documents from embassies and consulates in countries adjacent to Germany. These materials were sent to Warsaw and became part of the Foreign Ministry archives. Following the invasion of Poland, the ministry was evacuated along with a portion of its archives. Some records were intercepted by German and Russian forces, and a large portion of these has been lost permanently. With London providing a relatively safe environment for governmental activity, the records of the 1940-45 period have survived to a large extent intact, although some records from diplomatic posts abroad were destroyed in the post-war period in an effort to keep them from the new communist authorities in Poland.

The Hoover Archives is in possession of the complete set of the ministry's records covering the years 1939-1944, and some documents from 1945 are to be found within the collection. Supplementing these are the ministry's documents from 1945, which were found in Westminister Cathedral in 1980 and are now housed at the Sikorski Institute in London. Additional records are stored at the Pilsudski Institute in New Jersey. In terms of the size of its Polish Foreign Ministry collection, Hoover is equalled only by the Archiwum Akt Nowych in Warsaw, whose records cover only the inter-war period.

As its name would suggest, the Polish Foreign Ministry collection is especially important in terms of material concerning the history of various policy issues involving the Polish state and other countries. There are some records dating back to independence in 1918, as well as a substantial amount of sensitive material from the entire period before and during World War II, which were marked with the name of the current minister or other government official and kept separate from the rest of the records. For the most part, records of intelligence activities and other classified documents relating to military operations are not found in the collection. Most Polish military activity was under the control of the British, and for that reason records concerning this are generally not available. Material is to be found in the collection at Hoover concerning organizational, as opposed to operational, issues involving the Polish military, such as the formation, training and disposition of Polish forces on Soviet and British territory.
Attention should be drawn to material within the collection which concerns issues of special historical interest. These can be listed by country, region or topic:
THE SOVIET UNION

There is a substantial amount of documents in the collection concerning the Soviet occupation of Poland following the invasion of 1939, as well as its aftermath, including records of the deportation of Poles to the Soviet Union and their subsequent imprisonment or forced resettlement. There are numerous lists of deportees in the papers of the collection, records whose existence was hitherto unknown. The evacuation of former prisoners and the Polish army to the Middle East is also documented, as is the history of the rupture in diplomatic relations between the Soviet Union and Poland. Subsequent political and military agreements between the two countries are also recorded. There is extensive documentation on the formation of the Polish army on Soviet territory and various issues pertaining to this.
EASTERN EUROPE

Polish policies toward various Eastern and Central European countries are documented in the collection, as is the question of Soviet influence and control within these countries before and during World War II. There is significant material concerning Polish relations with Czechoslovakia and Ukraine, Soviet policies toward various nationalities incorporated into the Soviet Union, and general relations between other Eastern European countries and the Soviet Union. German and Soviet intelligence operations in Eastern Europe are also covered.
WESTERN EUROPE/UNITED STATES

There are substantial records in the collection concerning Poland's relations with its allies in World War II, and various shifts in British, French and American policies toward Poland are documented, as are various treaties concluded among the allies. Polish relations with the Vatican are documented, as is Polish participation in various international conferences. There is also a record of the deterioration of relations between Germany and Poland in the immediate pre-war period. While there is documentation of war crimes committed on Polish territory, there is less emphasis on the internal Polish situation than on external issues, military and diplomatic policy, and the organization of the Polish government-in-exile.
WAR CRIMES AND THE DESTRUCTION OF THE JEWS

There is extensive material in the collection concerning both Nazi and Soviet war crimes committed in Poland and elsewhere, as well as documentation concerning the appeals made by the Polish government on behalf of the victims of these actions. Efforts undertaken to save Jews in Poland and elsewhere in occupied Europe are recorded.
REFUGEES AND DISPLACED PERSONS
There is extensive documentation within the collection concerning the fate of Polish refugees and displaced persons within various countries.

Some explanation is necessary of the manner in which the collection is organized. The original system of classification of documents was established by the Polish Foreign Ministry, and this system changed as the ministry underwent a series of reorganizations during the inter-war period. In 1938, in order to facilitate communication with its various representatives, the ministry introduced a uniform index whereby documents were registered and classified. The hierarchies of this system are reflected in the collection itself, with the principal headings being:
1. The internal affairs and foreign policies of other countries
2. Polish relations with other countries
3. International organizations and institutions
4. Special matters, e.g., treaties and religious affairs
5. Emigration and the status of Poles abroad
6. Press and propaganda
7. Transportation
8. The internal structure of the foreign ministry and the organization of its diplomatic service
9. Consular issues
10. Polish internal affairs

In this system of classification, 200 numbers were left "empty," being available to be used for additional categories, which is in fact what happened during World War II. These numbers are maintained in the present organization of the collection, although some series do not appear due to a loss of documents prior to Hoover's acquisition of the collection. In some cases, material on the same subject may be found under more than one category due to an overlap in the general topic, as in the case of an issue affecting several countries or several departments within the Polish government. For example, the care of Polish refugees was the responsibility of the Ministry of Labor and Social Welfare, as well as the Foreign Ministry. Researchers interested in a particular topic are advised to search under other similar categories.

The Foreign Ministry Collection has been reduced in size over time, as many individual collections (from embassies and consulates), which did not originate from the Foreign Ministry itself, have been separated out from the main body of the documents. During the present reorganization of the collection, several of these separate series were identified, two of the most important being the collections of the Polish Legation to the Czechoslovak Government in London and the Polish Embassy in Dublin. The latter collection also contains material from the post-war period. Other, smaller collections (for the most part consisting individually of one box of material) include that of the Polish consulate in Lille, France and those of the following Polish embassies: Kuibyshev, London, Paris, Rome, Budapest, Bucharest, Belgrade, Copenhagen, Hague, Brussels, the League of Nations. These supplement already established collections in the Hoover Archives from other Polish embassies and consulates.

The bulk of the Foreign Ministry Collection is comprised of correspondence, telegrams, memoranda, minutes, clippings, statements of protocol and printed matter. Photographs constitute a separate file within the collection. The present work of organizing the collection began with a sequential rearrangement of all the folders, a process which restored the original series established by the Foreign Ministry. Much of the material had remained untouched from the time of its shipment to Hoover and had to be removed from its original file covers. The documents are grouped by series, which are subdivided chronologically and by individual categories, according to the importance of the material. This detailed classification allows for the ready indentification of thousands of names, organizations and subjects; it should also enhance the accessibility of eventual microfilm copies of the collection. It should be stressed, however, that the index to the register of the collection refers to the headings on the folders, not to their entire contents.

Until 1991, the collection was used by researchers in the form in which it had been originally shipped to Hoover. Following the current reorganization of the collection, a list of the previous numbering (of folders and boxes) has been preserved. It may be found in the last box of the collection.

The vast majority of the documents in this collection is in Polish, although some are in French and English. Variations in geographic place names reflect changes in borders, as in the case of Polish territory annexed by the Soviet Union, as well as changes in usage. The particularities of Polish orthography (characters and accents) have been omitted from the present register.

In the final stages of preparing the register of this collection, I was assisted by the efforts of others in editing the index and with general clerical support. My thanks go especially to Linda Bernard, who contributed months of work on the index. Others to whom I am grateful are Karen Horrigan, David Jacobs, Anne Kvittum, Carol Leadenham, Andrew Olah, Natasha Porfirenko, Dale Reed, and Dina Updegraff.

scopecontent.p: Collection of documents related to Polish corridor crisis and political status of city of Gdansk (Danzig)

did.unittitle: 1932. "Germany and the Polish Corridor". Speech by Julius Curtius, New York, Dec. 2. Mimeograph
1933. Documents illustrating the evolution of German territorial policy toward Poland, 1928-1932. Retyped copies
1937. Joint Polish-German declaration on the status of Gdansk. Drafts, Warsaw, July 14. Typescript and holograph
January. Report on talks of Jozef Beck with Adolf Hitler, Hermann Goering and Joseph Goebbels, Berlin, Jan. 13-14
September. Talks of Jozef Lipski with Hermann Goering, Sept. 16
October. Instructions of Jozef Beck for Jozef Lipski on Polish position in crisis with Germany, Oct. 31

November. Report of Jozef Lipski on talks with Joachim von Ribbentrop and Carl J. Burckhardt; notes on Burkhardt's visit to Warsaw; talks of Jozef Beck with German ambassador Hans Adolf von Moltke; letter to Arthur Greiser, President of Gdansk City Senate

December, 1-15. Letter of Marian Chodacki, Commissioner General of Poland, to Arthur Greiser; report of Carl Burckhardt to the secretary general of the League of Nations; instructions of Jozef Beck for Jozef Lipski on talks with Ribbentrop; letter to Arthur Greiser; report from the ambassador to England Edward Raczynski on talks with Frederick Halifax; reports of the commissioner general to Gdansk; excerpts from report of Lipski; aide-memoire of British Embassy

December, 15-31. Notes of Jozef Beck on British aide- memoire; letter from Burckhardt on consultations with British consul Sheperd; report of Edward Raczynski; report of Marian Chodacki on relations between Burckhardt and Hans Forster, Gdansk Chief of State, and on Burckhardt's trip to Berlin; consulatations with British authorities on taking the case of Gdansk to the League of Nations

January, 1-15. Note of government expert on introduction of new German law in Gdansk; letter of Arthur Greiser to Marian Chodacki; note on talks with Swedish charge d'affaires; telegrams from ambassadors in Bern and London; report of Beck on consultations with British ambassador; letter to Tytus Komarnicki delegating and instructing him on talks at the League of Nations

January, 16-31. Reports on talks with British diplomats in Warsaw and Geneva; instructions of Beck for Komarnicki; clippings from Gdansk press; communique of Comite des Trois; detailed report of Komarnicki on his mission at the League of Nations; instructions for Komarnicki; letter from Burckhardt to Komarnicki

February. Talks of Jan Szembek with von Moltke; Swedish declaration on Gdansk; report of Chojnacki on meeting with Greiser; note on Arciszewski's talks with Himmler; report on Himmler's train trip to Poland; telegram from Lipski on his meeting with Ribbentrop

March. Telegrams from Lipski and report on talks with Hitler and Goering; telegram from Raczynski; talks of Beck with von Moltke; response to Gdansk Volkstag election plans; report of Lipski on talks with Ribbentrop; Polish government memorandum to Germany; circulars and instructions of Beck; Government declaration; memorandum of Beck for Moltke

April. Instructions of Beck in case of armed confrontation; report on talks between Hitler and Gafencu; instructions of Beck for Polish diplomats; talks of Tomasz Arciszewski with British ambassador; talks of Beck with British ambassador; report on Hitler's speech; telegram of Juliusz Lukasiewicz to Ministry

May, 1-15. Instructions of Ministry; response to German memorandum; telegrams from Lukasiewicz; talks of Szembek with British ambassador; telegrams from ambassador to Hungary; clippings from Swiss press; instructional circulars; telegrams from embassies in Italy and Sweden; instructions for London Embassy; report on talks with French ministry official Arnal; telegrams from Chiczewski in Italy; telegrams from Raczynski; reports on talks with Norton, British Embassy adviser; note on conversation with Japanese Ambassador Sakoh

May, 16-31. Reports of Polish Embassy to Vatican; clippings from British press; political report from embassy in Paris; reports of Komarnicki from Geneva; Polish-British declaration in response to German threat; note on talks with secretary at French embassy; note on talks with Belgian envoy

June. Clippings from Swiss press; instructions of Beck for Chodacki. Report of Chodacki on talks with Burckhardt; report of Lipski on Burckhardt's talks with Weizsaecker and Ribbentrop; Beck to Komarnicki; talks of Arciszewski with Moltke; telegrams from Lipski; telegrams from Rome; note on talks between Szembek and Italian ambassador; report from ambassador in Paris; note on Reichswehr in Gdansk

July. Telegram from Georges Bonnet regarding French declarations toward Poland; telegram from Michal Lubienski on British position on conflict; telegram from Raczynski on Neville Chamberlain's declarations; report of Chodacki to Beck; telegram from Paris on Ribbentrop's letter to Bonnet; telegram from London on talks with Halifax
August. Perkowski, Deputy of General Commissioner in Gdansk, on talks between Burckhardt and Forster

Selected empty folders 659-661. Duplicate mimeographed materials on Polish-Soviet relations, history and internal situation of Soviet Union, deportations of Polish citizens. Instructional material for diplomatic course on international law and international relations, 1940-1944 662. Ministerial and other indexes used as guides in the organization of the collection
16 prints of individuals, most of them government employees, applying for passports at the Polish Foreign Ministry in Angers, France. Some photos signed on the back.
3 prints intercepted from a German soldier depicting Jewish mass graves and related burial ceremonies in the Lwow area.

13 prints depicting atrocities committed on the Jewish population by Germans in the Warsaw Ghetto, and the scenes resulting from hunger and poverty (some of the first images from the microfilm which reached the West through couriers).
24 prints depicting treatment of Soviet prisoners of war by the Germans on Polish territory, submitted to the Polish government on a microfilm delivered by couriers.
1 print depicting a ceremony with participation of Henri-Philippe Petain and his entourage.
15 prints depicting diplomatic ceremonies in Cuba with participation of the Polish Legation, including presentation of ambassadorial credentials.
1 print depicting the residence of the Polish Consulate General in Ottawa, Canada.
12 prints depicting refugee children from Soviet Union in Jangmar camp, India.
5 prints depicting Polish - Iranian youth tournament in Teheran, Iran, with participation of royal couple.
36 photos depicting Polish refugee children relocation centers in Uzbekistan, including of starving orphan boys at the time of their arrival, wearing rags, during or before their hospitalization.

32 photos depicting International Red Cross warehouses in Switzerland with boxes and barrels filled with medications, marked for delivery to Poland; Red Cross employees at work loading train wagons; and individual goods and products for February and June transports.
3 photos depicting railroad warehouses of Commission for Polish Relief in Geneva, Switzerland with boxes and cardboard drums destined for deliveries to Poland.
1 photo depicting 94 volumes of accounting records submitted with the annual report of the Financial Adviser to the Polish Embassy in the Soviet Union.
